meanings.definition: To make something less refined or cultured.
meanings.sent1: The artist vulgarised his painting by adding bright neon colors.
meanings.sent2: The classic novel was vulgarised in the movie adaptation.
meanings.sent3: The chef accidentally vulgarised the elegant dish by adding too much ketchup.
meanings.sent4: Her elegant speech was vulgarised by the sudden outburst of laughter.
meanings.sent5: The once beautiful garden was vulgarised by the addition of plastic flamingos.

meanings.sent1: The tabloid newspaper vulgarised the celebrity's private life.
meanings.sent2: The corrupt politician vulgarised the integrity of the government.
meanings.sent3: The comedian vulgarised the serious topic with his inappropriate jokes.
meanings.sent4: The graffiti vulgarised the historic monument.
meanings.sent5: The reality TV show vulgarised the concept of true love.

meanings.definition: To render something common or ordinary.
meanings.sent1: The mass production of the toy vulgarised its uniqueness.
meanings.sent2: The commercial vulgarised the traditional holiday song.
meanings.sent3: The fast-food chain vulgarised the idea of a gourmet burger.
meanings.sent4: The cheap materials vulgarised the once luxurious furniture.
meanings.sent5: The modern adaptation vulgarised the classic play.
